title: Soothing a Raw & Sore Nose (Plus, Decongestion Tips)

steps.title: Apply a soothing moisturizer to the outside of your nostrils.
steps.content: Apply a soothing moisturizer to the outside of your nostrils. Petroleum jellies like Vaseline and ointments like Neosporin can help soothe your irritated nose. Place a small amount of product on a cotton swab, then apply it around the entrance of each nostril. The extra moisture will not only relieve dryness, but it will also create a barrier against irritation from a runny nose. [1] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source If you don't have Vaseline or Neosporin handy, use your regular face lotion. It won't lock in moisture as effectively, but it’ll still give you relief.

steps.title: Buy tissues with lotion.
steps.content: Buy tissues with lotion . Splurging on high-quality facial tissue can go a long way toward soothing your nose. Look for products treated with lotion. These are softer on your nostrils and cause less damage when blowing your nose. Less chafing during nose-blowing means less irritation in the long run. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Soak your nose with a moist washcloth.
steps.content: Soak your nose with a moist washcloth. If your nose is badly chafed or bleeding, add warm moisture quickly to relieve the pain. Run a clean washcloth under hot water, then gently press it into the nostrils. Tilt your head back, breathe through your mouth, and leave the washcloth in place until it cools to room temperature. Apply petroleum jelly or Neosporin to your nose immediately after soaking it. Wash the washcloth immediately after using it.

steps.title: Try blowing your nose less.
steps.content: Try blowing your nose less. A runny or congested nose can feel terrible, and you may be tempted to blow your nose constantly. Though it may be hard, fight that urge and blow your nose only when necessary. If a little mucus runs out of your nose, gently dab it away instead of honking on a dry tissue and irritating your nose.

steps.title: Use a gentle nose-blowing technique to reduce chafing.
steps.content: Use a gentle nose-blowing technique to reduce chafing. Instead of taking a deep breath and blowing as hard as you can, blow gently through one nostril and then the other. Continue alternating nostrils until you feel your nose is clear. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Seek medical treatment for allergies.
steps.content: Seek medical treatment for allergies. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your runny or irritated nose is caused by seasonal allergies, contact your doctor. They can prescribe allergy medications to help manage and control your reactions. Whether you get allergy shots or take Flonase nasal spray when your nose starts running, treating the underlying allergy will help soothe your nose. [5] X Expert Source Alan O. Khadavi, MD, FACAAI Board Certified Allergist Expert Interview. 29 July 2020. Keep in mind that oral decongestants tend to make your mucous even dryer, which could increase irritation.

steps.title: Sit in a steamy room.
steps.content: Sit in a steamy room. Turn on the hot water in the shower, and close the door to keep all the steam in. Stay in the bathroom for 3 to 5 minutes or until you feel your sinuses clearing up. Gently blow your nose before leaving the room to let everything out. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source To save water, take a hot shower and then blow your nose when you get out. If you can access a sauna or steam room, consider heading there instead.

steps.title: Apply a warm compress to the bridge of your nose.
steps.content: Apply a warm compress to the bridge of your nose. Wet a washcloth and place it in the microwave until it's warm (not burning hot). Place the cloth across your nose and let it sit until it's cooled. The heat will loosen secretions or mucus from the nasal cavity. [7] X Research source Repeat the process before blowing your nose if necessary. Microwaving time will vary depending on your machine, so start with 30 seconds and add 15 seconds at a time.

steps.title: Flush your nose with saline spray.
steps.content: Flush your nose with saline spray . [8] X Expert Source Alan O. Khadavi, MD, FACAAI Board Certified Allergist Expert Interview. 29 July 2020. A quick mist of saline spray can help clear your nasal cavity and sinuses. Spray the bottle twice into each nostril to feel instant relief. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Purchase saline spray at your local drug store or pharmacy, or make saline spray at home with the following steps: Mix 8 fluid ounces (240 mL) of warm water with 1 ⁄ 2 tsp (0.010 c) of salt. Buy a suction bulb from the grocery store or pharmacy. Dip the end of the suction bulb into the solution and squeeze the bulb. Squirt the saline in the bulb into your nose.

steps.title: Try using a neti pot.
steps.content: Try using a neti pot . A neti pot looks like a miniature teapot and helps clear blocked sinus passages in the nose by flooding warm water through one nostril and out the other. Heat the water to at least 120 °F (49 °C). Then, let it cool to a comfortable temperature and fill the pot. Tilt your head to the left, and pour the water into your right nostril until it drains out of your left nostril. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Don’t use a neti pot if you live in an area with inadequate water treatment, as using untreated water could put your health at risk. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Drink warm tea throughout the day.
steps.content: Drink warm tea throughout the day. The throat and nose are closely connected, so drinking warm liquids can help warm up your nasal passage and help mucus flow more freely. Opt for your favorite tea or try a healing herbal tea if you’re fighting a cold. [12] X Research source Peppermint and clove teas are great for soothing sore throats and opening up your nasal passage.

steps.title: Exercise if you’re able to.
steps.content: Exercise if you’re able to. Physical activity may not be the best option if you’re bedridden with a cold or flu. But if allergies cause your excessive nose-blowing, some extra movement may be just what you need! Increasing your heart rate and breaking a sweat can help clear your nasal passage. So, go for a 15-minute jog or do an at-home workout to get your blood pumping. [13] X Research source Keep in mind where your allergies are coming from. For instance, it’s best to exercise indoors if you're allergic to pollen.

steps.title: Eat something spicy to open your airways.
steps.content: Eat something spicy to open your airways. Have you ever noticed that your nose starts to run when you eat extremely spicy foods? That’s because the food's heat burns your senses and opens your nasal passage. Snack on some hot salsa, peppers, or hot wings if you need a little help clearing your nose—just keep plenty of tissues nearby! [14] X Research source

steps.title: Invest in a humidifier to keep the air moist year-round.
steps.content: Invest in a humidifier to keep the air moist year-round. A common cause of a stuffy or irritated nose is dry air. Help moisten the air in your home or workspace all year round by setting up a humidifier. Set the machine to a humidity level between 30% and 50% to keep your sinuses happy and healthy. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Make sure to clean and add new water to your humidifier daily to avoid bacteria buildup.

steps.title: Massage your sinus area, so it's easier to blow your nose.
steps.content: Massage your sinus area, so it's easier to blow your nose. Place a few drops of rosemary, peppermint, or lavender oil on your fingertips. Then, use your index and middle fingers to apply gentle pressure to the forehead (frontal sinus), bridge of the nose and temples (orbital sinus), and area under the eyes (maxillary sinus). Use circular motions to move and loosen built-up mucus. [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Wash your face afterward to remove any excess oil. If you don’t have essential oils, no worries! Do this massage with clean, bare fingers.
